titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Attila Kotányi Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday May 4, 2019 at 03:00

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Jan Ceuleers on the Frederick W. Hilles Fund, 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials collection roughly maintain the order found at time of acquisition.

bioghist.head: Attila Kotányi
bioghist.p: Attila Kotányi (1924-2003) was a Hungarian poet, philosopher, and architect associated with the Situationist International.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Attila Kotányi Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, notes, index cards, notebooks, photographs, artwork, architectural drawings, blueprints, research materials, printed material, and other papers by or relating to Attila Kotanyi and documenting his life, work, and involvement with the Situationist International.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Attila Kotányi Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains letters to and from Attila Kotányi.

Also contains: a letter to Guy Debord (1963 October 11); a letter from Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Institute of Design in Chicago (1946 November 11); a postcard to Szabo (1957 August 21); a note from Hannes Böhringer (1983); a letter from Roberto Ohrt (1984 September 28); a letter from Raoul Vaneigem (circa 2000); letters in Hungarian from different correspondents (circa 1950s-1980s).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A debate on technical-pedagogical matters. Contains: a transcript of the debate, which concerned the teaching of architecture. Attila Kotányi was one of the participants.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes, written in English, about the uses of psychology, psychotherapy and its links to architecture. Also contains notes on the Brussels World Fair of 1958, and the role of UNESCO.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on psychology, alternatives for religion, and "la grande révision". Also contains notes on the "irrational" elements in Marxism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on Asger Jorn's interpretations on dialectics, the uses of a situationist critque, the meaning of de Sade for the urban planner, Friedrich Nietzsche's warnings concerning "socialism", the dangers of subtlety and of unnecessary complicated reasoning, and "la beauté c'est la promesse d'une fonction." Also contains notes on the danger and necessity of irrational factors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes taken during the fifth conference of the Situationist International, held in Göteborg, Sweden (1961 August 28-30).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on the themes discussed within the Situationist International. Also contains notes on the abolishing of reigning information systems in order to liberate general consciousness from the "raison d'état", real spontaneousness as opposed to the fake version that comes with the official addiction (i.e. television), the rhythm of meetings and separations within the Situationist International, and the role of time in art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a typescript entitled "Introduction et Apostyle à la critique cacoteuse." Also contains a draft of an announcement of "grand spectacle antisituationniste," as well as notes regarding "contre l'idéologie du hasard," and "pour la révalorisation commerciale de l'art, antisituationniste, ou l'art tout simplement."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on architecture, urban planning, philosophical subjects, Martin Heidegger's ideas on dwellings, and architecture as "oeuvre totale".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a notebook, titled "Ingolstadt," as well as handwritten notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on philosophy, gangsters, an illustrated fable of the wahlfish, and other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on Dada, and other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on architecture, with drawings and self portraits, as well as other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on Joseph Beuys and the Akademie of Düsseldor, along with self-portrait drawings, and other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on Michel Foucault, as well as Max Taut in Japan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on the contradictions of rational planning, as well as freedom and cybernetics. Also contains notes on the contradictions between scientific and religious attitudes regarding reality.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes regarding Guy Debord, the Baader-Meinhof Group, violence, and urban planning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on "form and function," technological and economical contexts, the search for meaning, art, and other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on social complexity, Paul Rudolph and mega structures, postmodernism, Venturi and Raunch, and other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on religion as an antidote for reductionism, and other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes on Christopher Lasch, Jean Baudrillard, Zen discipline, and other related subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains index cards with handwritten notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains index cards with handwritten notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains index cards with handwritten notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains drawings. Also contains a newspaper clipping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs of architectural models, as well as a photograph of a drip painting, and a photographic negative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains sketches for architectural and urban projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains stylized portraits and self portraits, as well as landscapes and abstracts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains large format impressionist and abstract artwork.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains drawings and blueprints for an urban project, created when Attila Kotányi worked at the Herbosch architectural office within Brussels (circa 1957). Also contains blueprints of a project designed by Attila Kotányi of artists' studios and apartments (circa 1965).

did.unittitle: Sanierung des Lebens, Sanierung der Stadt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains notes, in German, on city planning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains photocopied document with handwritten corrections and additions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains documents related to Attila Kotányi's teaching at the Düsseldorf Academy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains bound typescripts regarding the spirtual tradition of mankind, especially regarding cults and culture, and the anthropology of antiquity.

did.unittitle: Paul Wiener. Une manifestation du malaise dans la civilisation: le salopart

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a critique of pop art and nouveau réalisme.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains material regarding Friedrich Nietzsche and Meister Eckhardt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains material regarding Győző Határ, Magyar Balázs, Günter Rösch, and Gerhard Fehl.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains books with extensive marginalia, as well as exhibit catalogs and school material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a 1982 program from the Akademie der Architektenkammer Nordrhein-Westfalen, a photocopy of "Grundgedanken des Buddhismus," by Martin Brauen (1983 February), a photocopy of "Im Zeichen des Buddhismus" (1982), a photocopy of "Wir sind die Autoren unserer eigenen Geschichte," by Monica Moebius, a newspaper clipping, a photocopy of "Proof In Philosopy," by Professor Charles Perelman (Hibbert Journal, 1954), Endre Bíró translation work regarding James Joyce, a photostat of "Renate Marschner: Die Frankfurter Schule," a photostat of "Bodenproben," by Hannes Böhringer (1987), and a photocopy of "Noten Zum Surrealismus," by Jacob Taubes (1966).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains school catalogs, with handwritten marginalia and placed-in notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Both periodicals have extensive marginalia, by Attila Kotányi.

did.unittitle: Der Französische Strukturalismus, by Günther Schiwy, book

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains extensive marginalia, with a laid-in note.

Paul Ricoeur ou la liberté selon l'espérance, by Michel Philibert, book

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains extensive marginalia, with a placed-in note.

scopecontent.p: Contains extensive marginalia, with laid-in notes.

scopecontent.p: Contains extensive marginalia, with laid-in notes.

La dialectique, by Paul Foulquié, book

scopecontent.p: Contains extensive marginalia, with placed-in notes.
